awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SaTC: CORE: Small: Detecting Accounts Involved in Influence Campaigns on Social Media
awd_abstract_narration:
The growing popularity of online social networks has opened the door to false information being disseminated by malicious actors. Hostile nation states are orchestrating disinformation campaigns in the United States with the goal of influencing public discourse or pushing talking points that favor a particular country’s agenda. These campaigns are typically carried out with the help of fake social media accounts known as trolls, which pose as fictitious personas. These trolls interact with each other and with unsuspecting social network users with the goal of polarizing discussion and furthering false narratives. Despite the serious threat that disinformation poses to our society, social networks are struggling to keep up with the threat, resorting to reactive measures that remove malicious accounts after the fact. The goal of this project is to develop techniques able to automatically identify troll accounts on social networks so that they can be more swiftly removed.

To carry out this project, the investigators are collecting information about the troll accounts identified by Twitter and Reddit as belonging to several foreign countries’ disinformation campaigns. These data are used to train machine learning algorithms able to automatically identify other troll accounts on Twitter and Reddit. The project follows two parallel research tasks. In the first task, the research team aims to train supervised learning algorithms to learn the typical behavior of known troll accounts, with the goal of identifying more accounts that behave similarly and are therefore part of the same disinformation campaign. Preliminary results show that troll accounts exhibit peculiar interaction patterns that are uncommon in real accounts. In the second task, the researchers will work towards identifying traits that are typical of troll accounts regardless of the campaign that they belong to, and use transfer learning techniques to identify emerging disinformation campaigns. Students are involved at all stages of the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new state-of-the-art techniques to identify inauthentic accounts on online platforms that are used to carry out fraudulent activities. While existing techniques focus on learning the characteristics of the harmful content to better identify it, this project focused on the observation that inauthentic accounts simulate benign activity to appear legitimate. By training machine learning models on this simulated activity, the research team developed content-agnostic machine learning systems that are more robust and resistant to changes in content than existing ones. 


The results from this project were disseminated to the scientific community by publishing several peer reviewed papers at leading computer security venues, including the IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy, ACM Conference on Computer and Communication Security (CCS), the International Symposium on Research in Attacks, Intrusion and Defenses (RAID), as well as venues like the AAAI International Conference on Web and Social Media (ICWSM), ACM Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW). Several of these papers won awards. The Principal Investigators gave invited talks nationally and internationally where they disseminated this research, and the techniques and results developed as part of this project were incorporated into their teaching materials for college classes at both the undergraduate and graduate level. The results of this project were also disseminated among high school students through guest lectures in summer schools. Finally, dissemination among the general public was achieved through engagement with popular news media outlets like Wired and ABC News.


Last Modified: 08/21/2024
Modified by: Gianluca Stringhini
